item.title: Republicans Are Stuck Between President and Party on the Stimulus
item.description: The House and Senate finally passed an economic relief package, and the deal was blessed as a “down payment” by President-elect Joe Biden. But President Trump is leaving office as he came in: a disrupter.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Buried in Covid Relief Bill: Billions to Soothe the Richest
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Joe Manchin III, Democrat of West Virginia, at the Capitol last week. He said leadership intentionally waited until the last minute to unveil final proposals to the spending bill.
item.description: The voluminous coronavirus relief and spending bill that blasted through Congress on Monday includes provisions — good, bad and just plain strange — that few lawmakers got to read.
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater, Jesse Drucker and Rebecca R. Ruiz

item.title: Stimulus Deal Q&A: Second Check, Unemployment Insurance and More
item.media:credit: Robert Neubecker
item.description: Lawmakers agreed to issue stimulus payments of $600 and distribute a federal unemployment benefit of $300 for 11 weeks. But that money will take time to start arriving.
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.dc:creator: Tara Siegel Bernard and Ron Lieber

item.title: Declines in Income and Spending Raise Worries About Economy’s State
item.description: The federal government’s data showed personal income fell for the second straight month while jobless claims remained high. Here’s the latest on the economy.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: President Trump: Unhappy, Unleashed and Unpredictable
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump returning to the White House after the Army-Navy football game earlier this month. Mr. Trump has made few public appearances in the last few weeks.
item.description: President Trump remains the most powerful man in the world, but powerless to achieve what he most wants: to avoid leaving office as a loser.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Haberman and Michael S. Schmidt

item.title: Trump Pardons Four Blackwater Guards and Two Russia Inquiry Figures
item.media:credit: Carolyn Kaster/Associated Press
item.media:description: George Papadopoulos served 12 days in jail for lying to the F.B.I. about his contacts with Russian intermediaries during the 2016 presidential race. He was pardoned by the president on Tuesday.
item.description: The pre-Christmas wave of 20 pardons and commutations are not likely to be the last before Mr. Trump leaves office on Jan. 20.
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
item.dc:creator: Maggie Haberman and Michael S. Schmidt

item.title: U.K. Tightens Restrictions as Alarm About Variant Grows
item.description: The agreement means the companies will supply a total of 200 million doses, enough to vaccinate 100 million Americans. Here’s the latest on the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Why Covid Antibody Drugs Go Unused as Need Soars
item.media:credit: Floyd Medical Center
item.media:description: A box of Eli Lilly’s antibody treatment, bamlanivimab, at Floyd Medical Center in Rome, Ga. Despite worries that the drug would be scarce, the hospital has infused about 100 patients and has not had to turn anyone away.
item.description: While such treatments are promising, their use has been slowed by testing lags, overwhelmed hospitals and a perception the therapies are only for well-connected people.
item.dc:creator: Katie Thomas and Rebecca Robbins

item.title: For Millions of Jobless, Christmas Is a Season to Endure, Not Celebrate
item.media:credit: Sebastian Hidalgo for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tresa Watson, right, with her grandson Khalil and his mother, Rachel Rucinski, at their home in Milwaukee. Ms. Watson was laid off in March.
item.description: Even with new federal aid on the way, many Americans face a holiday of tough choices, trying to celebrate while dealing with pressing needs.
item.dc:creator: Nelson D. Schwartz and Gillian Friedman

item.title: The Virus That Stole Most of 2020 Now Steals Christmas, Too
item.media:credit: Alessandro Grassani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Milan this month. A surge in infections, a new fast-spreading strain of the virus and mounting deaths have led the authorities to shut down in the prelude to Christmas.
item.description: Across Italy and beyond, those who lost loved ones this year had looked forward to a holiday with the rest of their friends and relatives. But for many, it’s not to be.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz

item.title: It’s Peak Season for Tamales in Los Angeles
item.media:credit: Jessica Pons for The New York Times
item.media:description: At her outdoor kitchen in Montebello, Calif., Claudia Serrato and her family make tamales with blue corn and braised bison.
item.description: Big tamaladas are canceled this year, but many of the city’s tamaleras press on because tamales, along with the cultures and microeconomies they sustain, are essential.
item.dc:creator: Tejal Rao

item.title: Police Took Their Son Away. Then the Merchants of Hope Showed Up.
item.media:credit: Yagazie Emezi for The New York Times
item.media:description: The bedroom of Chijioke Iloanya, who disappeared eight years ago. He was last seen at a police station run by the feared unit known as SARS.
item.description: The police seize and kill young men in Nigeria. Then pastors, lawyers and so-called human rights advocates squeeze money out of their families, promising to help find them.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean and Ben Ezeamalu

item.title: A Podcast Answers a Fast-Food Question That Nobody Is Asking
item.media:credit: Michelle Groskopf for The New York Times
item.media:description: On the podcast, Brian Thompson plays an earnest, eager naïf, also named Brian Thompson, who regards himself as an intrepid seeker of truth and seems to think he’s digging into a riddle for the ages.
item.description: Intentionally inane, “Whatever Happened to Pizza at McDonald’s?” satirizes the business of podcasting.
item.category: Whatever Happened to Pizza at McDonald's? (Radio Program)
item.dc:creator: David Segal

item.title: A Maine Paper Mill’s Unexpected Savior: China
item.description: First came the Buddhist monks. Then the feng shui consultant. In the summer, a battered New England mill town greeted the new owner of its factory — one of the richest tycoons in China.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Barry and Tristan Spinski

item.title: Pundit Accountability
item.media:credit: Jeff Swensen/Getty Images
item.media:description: Voters waited to cast their ballots on Election Day in Cranberry Township, Pa.
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt

item.title: West Point Cheating Scandal: What to Know
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker/The New York Times
item.description: More than 70 West Point cadets have been accused of cheating on an exam, the institution's largest academic scandal in decades.
item.category: Cathedral Church of St John the Divine (Manhattan, NY)
item.dc:creator: Troy Closson

item.title: The Year in Good News
item.media:credit: Bettmann Archives, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Like a prospector on the Klondike at the turn of the 20th century, Bianca Giaever panned the good news in the 700 listener messages we received.
item.description: In a bleak year, our listeners offer some brightness — from all over the world.
item.dc:creator: Bianca Giaever

item.title: Agents of Change
item.description: Kerri Greenidge discusses two books about African-Americans in the years before the Civil War, and Neal Gabler talks about “Catching the Wind,” his biography of Edward Kennedy.

item.title: Bonus: Kara Swisher and Nick Kristof Discuss Pornhub and Mastercard
item.media:credit: Illustration by The New York Times; photograph by Celeste Sloman for The New York Times
item.description: They also discuss the slippery slope from guns to sugary cereals.

item.title: Meet Alex Padilla, California’s Next Senator
item.media:credit: Rich Pedroncelli/Associated Press
item.media:description: California Secretary of State Alex Padilla in January 2019. Being chosen to serve as a U.S. senator is “immensely humbling,” he said.
item.description: Wednesday: He will be the state’s first Latino senator. Also: Shirley Weber will be secretary of state.
item.dc:creator: Jill Cowan and Shawn Hubler

item.title: Will Trump Force Principled Conservatives to Start Their Own Party? I Hope So
item.media:credit: Samuel Corum for The New York Times
item.description: American politics will be shaped by the influence of the monarch of Mar-a-Lago.
item.dc:creator: Thomas L. Friedman

item.title: During the Coronavirus, Feminism Has Failed Women
item.description: If the pandemic undid three decades of progress on gender equality, one has to wonder: How real was that progress in the first place?
item.dc:creator: Kim Brooks

item.title: Can Joe Biden Make American Politics Decent Again?
item.description: The new year will prove whether we have any decency left in us.
item.dc:creator: Frank Bruni

item.title: Coronavirus Vaccine Distribution Could Get Chaotic
item.media:credit: Alex Welsh for The New York Times
item.media:description: A hospital staff member receiving the coronavirus vaccine in California last week.
item.description: There are already signs that distribution will be messy, confusing and chaotic.
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Rosenthal

item.title: Are You Sure You Want to Go Back to the Office?
item.description: The future of work is flexibility.
item.dc:creator: Anne Helen Petersen

item.title: Trump’s Team Eyes the Exits
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.description: Farewell, henchmen.
item.dc:creator: Michelle Cottle

item.title: Covid-19 Changed Our Restaurant's Business Overnight
item.description: In a world where everything was changing, the menu at a small New Orleans restaurant also had to adapt. Not everyone seemed to get that.
item.dc:creator: Richard Horner

item.title: The Life of Calvin Haworth, a Veteran Who Helped Raise His Granddaughters After Unspeakable Loss
item.description: “Cause of Life” celebrates the messy, tenacious, and extraordinary lives of five people we lost to Covid-19.
item.dc:creator: Ben Proudfoot

item.title: Ancient DNA Is Changing How We Think About the Caribbean
item.media:credit: Kayana Szymczak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Scientists now have data concerning the entire genomes of more than 260 people of the ancient Caribbean.
item.description: New research delivers surprising findings about Indigenous people in the region before contact with Europeans.
item.dc:creator: David Reich and Orlando Patterson

item.title: Sports Helped Me Get Through the Coronavirus Pandemic
item.description: Despite its risks, watching pro sports has given so many of us a needed reprieve.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Randle

item.title: What’s It Like to Live in a Nursing Home During a Pandemic?
item.media:credit: Getty Images
item.description: Tell us what you or your peers have experienced.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times Opinion

item.title: History of Tiki Bars and Cultural Appropriation
item.media:credit: Olivia McGiff
item.description: Tiki bars are a beverage industry mainstay — with a painful and underexamined past. Can the format be repaired?
item.dc:creator: Sammi Katz and Olivia McGiff

item.title: Carey Mulligan Won’t Let Hollywood Off the Hook
item.media:credit: Danny Kasirye for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mulligan said of one review that focused on her looks: “I was like, ‘Really? For this film, you’re going to write something that is so transparent? Now? In 2020?’”
item.description: The actress delivered the performance of her career in the dark comedy “Promising Young Woman.” Then came those with their tired views of women.
item.dc:creator: Kyle Buchanan

item.title: How The New England Patriots' Dynasty Fell
item.media:credit: Mark Brown/Getty Images
item.media:description: The end of the Patriots’ dynasty came in Miami, on a field where they had enjoyed years of victories.
item.description: Empires never fall in a day. The Patriots have been quietly crumbling from within for years.
item.dc:creator: Mike Tanier

item.title: Sloan Kettering Paid $1.5 Million Severance to a Cancer Doctor Forced Out Over Conflicts
item.media:credit: Jeenah Moon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan.
item.description: Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center gave Dr. José Baselga a payout after he resigned under fire in 2018 over his ties to health care companies.
item.dc:creator: Katie Thomas and Charles Ornstein

item.title: Baltimore Building Explosion Sends 21 to Hospitals
item.media:credit: Jerry Jackson/The Baltimore Sun, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Two people were pulled to safety from a window-washing platform after the explosion, the authorities said.
item.description: The explosion happened on the 16th floor of the Baltimore Gas and Electric Company building. The cause was not immediately clear, but the utility said it was likely a construction accident.
item.dc:creator: Johnny Diaz

item.title: Yonkers Car Crash: 5 Men Die as Car Splits in Half
item.media:description: Surveillance video from a nearby gas station shows the collision that killed five men.
item.description: A speeding driver collided with a car carrying four recent high school graduates from Yonkers, N.Y.
item.dc:creator: Kimiko de Freytas-Tamura

item.title: Fraser Island Blaze Began With Campfire, Australian Officials Say
item.media:credit: Queensland Fire and Emergency Services, via Reuters
item.media:description: A bushfire on Fraser Island in Australia on Nov. 30. The authorities say the conflagration started with an illegal campfire.
item.description: The police said the men started an illegal campfire, but experts said the region would remain vulnerable to more fires as climate change worsens dry conditions.
item.dc:creator: Livia Albeck-Ripka

item.title: Charges Filed in Michaela Garecht Kidnapping Case After 32 Years
item.media:credit: FBI/Fremont Police Department, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A 1988 poster after Michaela Garecht was kidnapped from a grocery store parking lot in Hayward, Calif.
item.description: Witnesses saw Michaela Garecht kidnapped in Northern California in 1988. This week the authorities charged an incarcerated man with murder during a kidnapping.
item.dc:creator: Christine Hauser

item.title: Ancient DNA Shows Humans Settled Caribbean in 2 Distinct Waves
item.media:credit: Kristen Grace
item.media:description: Taíno ceramic vessels from eastern Dominican Republic, circa A.D. 1400.
item.description: Millions of people living on the islands today inherited genes from the people who made them home before Europeans arrived.
item.dc:creator: Carl Zimmer

item.title: Why Israel Faces a Fourth Election in Just Two Years
item.media:credit: Amir Cohen/Reuters
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, center, is again fighting for political survival.
item.description: What to know as Israel gears up for another vote, this time set for March 23.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner

item.title: William Winter, Reform-Minded Mississippi Governor, Dies at 97
item.media:credit: Rogelio V. Solis/Associated Press
item.media:description: William F. Winter in 2008. After serving as governor of Mississippi, he spent nearly three decades campaigning for racial reconciliation.
item.description: In his single term, he fought to improve his state’s education system. He later threw himself into civil rights work.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen

item.title: The Cons of Learning Pods
item.media:credit: Joyce Hesselberth
item.description: It turns out that organizing and operating an independent one-room schoolhouse from your backyard is…a lot of work.
item.dc:creator: Ronda Kaysen

item.title: How Will We Eat in 2021? 11 Predictions to Chew On
item.description: Meal kits from your favorite restaurant, snacks that help you sleep and other ways the food world may respond in a year of big changes.
item.dc:creator: Kim Severson

item.title: 4 Things Parents Learned From Their Kids in 2020
item.media:credit: Ricardo Nagaoka for The New York Times
item.media:description: Karen Pomerantz, left, of Portland, Ore., discovered that both of her children, including her daughter, Zoey, right, became especially imaginative during the pandemic.
item.description: Several say the pandemic helped them develop closer relationships with their children and become better parents.
item.dc:creator: Christina Caron

item.title: 2021 Travel Guide: Covid Restrictions, Vaccine, Flight Cancellations, Cruises and More
item.media:credit: Christian Hartmann/Reuters
item.media:description: Travelers and the travel industry are looking forward to a brighter 2021. Here, an airplane lands at sunrise at Charles-de-Gaulle Airport near Paris.
item.description: As 2020 ends, and with vaccination against the coronavirus ramping up, would-be travelers wonder what they can expect in the coming year, and beyond. Here’s what we know.
item.dc:creator: Tariro Mzezewa, Ceylan Yeginsu, Elaine Glusac and Sarah Firshein

item.title: One Big Pop Star + One Big Pop Star = an Easier Path to No. 1
item.media:description: Cardi B and Megan Thee Stallion’s “WAP” was perhaps the ultimate power duet of 2020.
item.description: Major artists looking to top the Hot 100 this year turned to a familiar formula made all the more powerful by the proliferation of fandoms online.
item.dc:creator: Lindsay Zoladz

item.title: In ‘Soul’ on Disney+, Pixar Has Its First Black Lead Character
item.description: Mindful of animation’s history of racist imagery, the studio aimed to make the jazz pianist at the center of the film as specific as possible.
item.dc:creator: Charles Solomon

item.title: Moms on the Frontlines
item.media:credit: Desiree Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cecilia Duran, 38, a New York City midwife, had Covid-19 when she was 10-weeks pregnant with the baby she is posing with here.
item.description: Health care workers are still fighting to keep their homes and communities safe.
item.dc:creator: Jessica Grose

item.title: 8 Fearless N.B.A. Season Predictions
item.media:credit: Mark Mulligan/Houston Chronicle, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The outlook for James Harden is now about when, not if, he will be traded from the Houston Rockets.
item.description: Houston’s James Harden is widely expected to be traded soon. But Kevin Love? Zach LaVine? LaMarcus Aldridge? They could be on the move, too.
item.dc:creator: Marc Stein

item.title: Meet the People Who Can’t Bring You ‘Messiah’ This Year
item.description: Listen as nine performers guide you through the emotional arc of Handel’s classic, from comfort to grief to jubilation.
item.dc:creator: Corinna da Fonseca-Wollheim

item.title: The New Covid Variant in the UK: Questions and Answers
item.description: A newly identified variant of the SARS-CoV-2 virus appears to be more contagious than established ones. Here’s what scientists know.
item.dc:creator: Carl Zimmer and Benedict Carey

item.title: To Study Blinking, a Scientist Needed a Literal Bird’s Eye View
item.media:credit: Yorzinski, Biology Letters, 2020
item.media:description: A grackle, outfitted with cameras to observe its blinking.
item.description: It took a customized headpiece to monitor when and how much a grackle blinked in flight.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Preston

item.title: What People With Allergies Should Know About Covid Vaccines
item.media:credit: Jenna Schoenefeld for The New York Times
item.media:description: Vaccinations underway in Orange, Calif., on Wednesday.
item.description: Four people so far have had allergic reactions after getting the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine. Experts say that shouldn’t deter most people from getting a jab.
item.dc:creator: Katherine J. Wu

item.title: This Solstice, Solace for the Darkness
item.media:credit: Alberto Valdes/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: An Indigenous Mapuche girl watched the solar eclipse from Chile on Monday.
item.description: A rare conjunction of planets serves as a reminder that there is more to the universe than just ourselves.
item.dc:creator: Dennis Overbye

item.title: George Clooney on ‘The Midnight Sky’ and Donald Trump
item.media:credit: Magdalena Wosinska for The New York Times
item.media:description: Clooney is optimistic about the future of theaters: “People want to get out of their house — I got twins, man!”
item.description: His new movie is on Netflix, but the actor-director says theaters won’t go away and Hollywood will be fine. He’s not so sure about Washington.
item.dc:creator: Kyle Buchanan

item.title: These Bacon and Eggs Practically Cook Themselves
item.media:credit: Andrew Purcell for The New York Times. Food Stylist: Carrie Purcell.
item.description: A big holiday breakfast is great — unless you’re the one stuck making it. This sheet-pan recipe is the solution.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Ko

item.title: Spelling Bee
item.media:credit: The New York Times
item.description: Use 7 letters to make as many words as you can.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: The Crossword, Tiles and More
item.media:credit: The New York Times
item.description: Solve the daily puzzle edited by Will Shortz, or try out other games like the Mini and Vertex.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Vertex
item.media:credit: The New York Times
item.description: Connect the dots to reveal the hidden picture.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Twitter Will Reset @POTUS Account To 0 Followers After Biden Transition
item.description: The President-elect's transition team is pushing back against the decision from Twitter, which is a reversal from the last presidential transition.
item.content:encoded:
The President-elect's transition team is pushing back against the decision from Twitter, which is a reversal from the last presidential transition.

(Image credit: Tom Brenner/Getty Images)
item.dc:creator: Reese Oxner

item.title: What's At Stake With Trump's Threat: COVID Relief And A Government Shutdown
item.description: President Trump has introduced a round of Christmas chaos that imperils direct payments to millions of Americans suffering due to the economic impacts of the coronavirus pandemic.
item.content:encoded:
President Trump has introduced a round of Christmas chaos that imperils direct payments to millions of Americans suffering due to the economic impacts of the coronavirus pandemic.

(Image credit: Julie Bennett/AP)
item.dc:creator: Domenico Montanaro

item.title: For Overwhelmed And Burnt Out COVID-19 Contact Tracers, Help Is (Hopefully) Coming
item.description: NPR's latest survey finds the contact tracing workforce now tops 70,000, a dramatic increase in the last two months. But to truly meet the growing demand, new federal funding will be key.
item.content:encoded:
NPR's latest survey finds the contact tracing workforce now tops 70,000, a dramatic increase in the last two months. But to truly meet the growing demand, new federal funding will be key.

(Image credit: John Moore/Getty Images)
item.dc:creator: Selena Simmons-Duffin

item.title: Biden Administration: Here's Who Has Been Named So Far
item.description: President-elect Joe Biden and his transition team are expected to roll out a slew of nominations for their administration before Inauguration Day. Here's whom they've officially announced.
item.content:encoded:
President-elect Joe Biden and his transition team are expected to roll out a slew of nominations for their administration before Inauguration Day. Here's whom they've officially announced.

(Image credit: Caroline Amenabar/NPR)
item.dc:creator: Elena Moore

item.title: How COVID-19 Became A 'Tremendous Windfall' For The Ultra Rich
item.description: "You have a group of 650 people whose wealth has gone up a trillion dollars since mid-March," says Chuck Collins of the Institute for Policy Studies. He recommends taxing a portion of those gains.
item.content:encoded: "You have a group of 650 people whose wealth has gone up a trillion dollars since mid-March," says Chuck Collins of the Institute for Policy Studies. He recommends taxing a portion of those gains.
item.dc:creator: Terry Gross

item.title: Russian Lawmakers Pass Bills That Could Block Social Media Sites — And Stifle Dissent
item.description: One law would allow for the blocking of foreign websites that it says "discriminate" against Russian media, while another would allow people convicted of slander to be jailed for up to two years.
item.content:encoded:
One law would allow for the blocking of foreign websites that it says "discriminate" against Russian media, while another would allow people convicted of slander to be jailed for up to two years.

(Image credit: Dmitry Astakhov/Sputnik/AFP via Getty Images)
item.dc:creator: Laurel Wamsley

item.title: A 'Real Easy' Choice: Biden Introduces Education Pick Miguel Cardona
item.description: A lifelong educator, Cardona is the third Latino candidate Biden's put forward for a Cabinet post. Wednesday, he spoke of the challenges schools have faced this year: "I've lived those challenges."
item.content:encoded:
A lifelong educator, Cardona is the third Latino candidate Biden's put forward for a Cabinet post. Wednesday, he spoke of the challenges schools have faced this year: "I've lived those challenges."

(Image credit: Carolyn Kaster/AP)
item.dc:creator: Elissa Nadworny

item.title: The Coronavirus Has Reached Antarctica. Now It's On Every Continent
item.description: Thirty-six people stationed at the General Bernardo O'Higgins Riquelme Antarctic base had tested positive for the virus, Chilean officials said this week.
item.content:encoded:
Thirty-six people stationed at the General Bernardo O'Higgins Riquelme Antarctic base had tested positive for the virus, Chilean officials said this week.

(Image credit: Chilean Army/Reuters)
item.dc:creator: Brakkton Booker

item.title: Mask Up! How Public Health Messages Collide With Facebook's Political Ads Ban
item.description: Nearly two months after Election Day, Facebook still prohibits political ads. The ban is frustrating some elected leaders who say it makes it harder to get out information about the pandemic.
item.content:encoded:
Nearly two months after Election Day, Facebook still prohibits political ads. The ban is frustrating some elected leaders who say it makes it harder to get out information about the pandemic.

(Image credit: Los Angeles County)
item.dc:creator: Shannon Bond

item.title: The Story Of 1-Year-Old Abdullah Is The Story Of Yemen
item.description: His parents traveled 15 hours by bus to bring him to a clinic to save his life. He weighed 6 pounds. And he could be one of the fortunate ones.

His parents traveled 15 hours by bus to bring him to a clinic to save his life. He weighed 6 pounds. And he could be one of the fortunate ones.

item.title: Coronavirus World Map: Tracking The Spread Of The Outbreak
item.description: A map of confirmed COVID-19 cases and deaths around the world. The respiratory disease has spread rapidly across six continents and has killed at least 1 million globally.

A map of confirmed COVID-19 cases and deaths around the world. The respiratory disease has spread rapidly across six continents and has killed at least 1 million globally.

item.title: Coronavirus Is Surging: How Severe Is Your State's Outbreak?
item.description: View NPR's maps and graphics to see where COVID-19 is hitting hardest in the U.S., which state outbreaks are growing and which are leveling off.

item.title: U.S. Reaches Deal With Pfizer For 100 Million More Vaccine Doses
item.description: The new deal effectively doubles the federal government's order from the company. Pfizer says the U.S. government has agreed to pay $1.95 billion for the additional doses.
item.content:encoded:
The new deal effectively doubles the federal government's order from the company. Pfizer says the U.S. government has agreed to pay $1.95 billion for the additional doses.

(Image credit: Andrew Harnik/AP)
item.dc:creator: Merrit Kennedy

item.title: We All Know Smoke Is Bad For Your Health. It Could Be Worse Than You Think
item.description: Could smoke carry disease-causing microorganisms? "It's a very new idea to think of smoke as having a living component," says Leda Kobziar, co-author of an article that explores this theory.
item.content:encoded:
Could smoke carry disease-causing microorganisms? "It's a very new idea to think of smoke as having a living component," says Leda Kobziar, co-author of an article that explores this theory.

item.title: Congress Gets COVID-19 Vaccine, But Members Fight Over Who Should Have Priority
item.description: Top leaders and rank-and-file members are getting the first wave of COVID-19 vaccines. It could speed up the return to business as usual. But some lawmakers say members should wait behind others.
item.content:encoded:
Top leaders and rank-and-file members are getting the first wave of COVID-19 vaccines. It could speed up the return to business as usual. But some lawmakers say members should wait behind others.

item.title: Trump urges Congress to amend 'wasteful' coronavirus aid bill
item.description: He asks lawmakers to "remove wasteful and unnecessary items", calling the package "a disgrace".

item.title: Twitter to wipe Trump's followers before Biden handover
item.description: The social media giant previously allowed President Trump to inherit Barack Obama's followers.

item.title: Dr Deborah Birx: White House virus expert quits over holiday travel
item.description: Dr Deborah Birx says the criticism she has faced for a family get-together is "very difficult".

item.title: UN criticises Trump's pardons for Blackwater guards jailed over Iraq killings
item.description: Four American contractors were jailed over the killing of 14 Iraqi civilians in Baghdad in 2007.

item.title: Joe Biden: 'Darkest days in the battle against Covid are ahead'
item.description: President-elect Biden urges Americans to remain vigilant and prepare for tens of thousands more deaths.

item.title: Karima Baloch: Pakistani rights activist found dead in Toronto
item.description: Karima Baloch, who was living in exile, was named in the BBC's annual list of 100 inspirational women.

item.title: Muslim-Canadian's 'first Christmas' goes viral
item.description: As a Christmas first-timer, Mohammad Hussain shared his unique perspective on the holiday on Twitter.

item.title: Lawmakers are in wait-and-see mode after the President surprisingly rebuked the massive and painstakingly negotiated coronavirus relief bill
item.description: • Trump throws Covid relief bill in doubt • Struggling Americans blast stimulus bill

item.title: President Trump throws Covid relief bill in doubt
item.description: President Donald Trump on Tuesday said he is asking for changes to the coronavirus relief bill passed by Congress, leaving the future of the $900 billion stimulus in doubt.

item.title: Listen to Trump's sudden stipulation for Covid-19 stimulus bill
item.description: President Trump issued a sudden pre-Christmas demand for changes to a desperately needed $900 billion pandemic relief bill that could potentially risk shattering the bipartisan compromise reached by Democrats and Republicans. CNN's Joe Johns reports.

item.title: Struggling Americans blast bill as too little, too late
item.description: Mallory Ware feels that Congress has abandoned her, her family and all struggling Americans amid the recession and worsening pandemic.

item.title: Why Ossoff agrees with Trump on increased direct payments
item.description: Georgia Senate-challenger Jon Ossoff reacts to the coronavirus relief bill recently passed by Congress, calling for increased direct stimulus payments for Americans struggling during the pandemic.

item.title: Analysis: Trump is right, $600 isn't enough. But $2,000 isn't either
item.description: After months of failed negotiations and political feuding, Congress finally approved a $900 billion relief package this week, nearly nine months after the record $2.2 trillion passed in March, and against the backdrop of a country riddled with economic peril and surging coronavirus cases.

item.title: Three big ways small business would benefit from the relief bill
item.description: Given how much the pandemic has hammered small businesses, three big changes to the Paycheck Protection Program are likely to come as a welcome relief.

item.title: Voting machine company executive sues Trump allies for defamation
item.description: • Giuliani told to preserve all records as lawyers for Dominion warn legal action is 'imminent' • Opinion: The real reason Trump is failing to overturn the election

item.title: Trump goes on a rampage with pardons, veto threats and Covid denial
item.description: • Survivors of Blackwater massacre in Iraq slam Trump's pardons • Opinion: Trump's ridiculous exit strategy

item.title: Actor organizes maskless caroling protests as California's cases surge
item.description: Actor Kirk Cameron is facing criticism for organizing at least two events in Southern California in recent weeks, where dozens of mask-less people stood shoulder-to-shoulder to sing Christmas carols in protest of state and local stay-at-home mandates.

item.title: Fox News hosts criticize holiday travel guidance
item.description: See Fox News anchors Tucker Carlson and Laura Ingraham mock CDC guidance around holiday travel.

item.title: Nine critically injured in Baltimore building explosion, partial roof collapse
item.description: At least 23 people were injured, nine critically, after a partial roof collapse and explosion Wednesday in downtown Baltimore, according to the fire department.

item.title: Tensions intensify between Biden and Pentagon over stalled transition briefings
item.description: President-elect Joe Biden's transition team on Wednesday disputed suggestions from Pentagon officials who questioned the accuracy of Biden's assertion a day earlier that the Department of Defense has refused to brief his team on the massive cyberattack on government agencies and major American technology and accounting companies.

item.title: Education secretary nominee says he is 'as American as apple pie'
Florida governor plans to sign executive order to ensure seniors are vaccinated first
Cuomo: This is a very bad situation President is creating
item.description: President Donald Trump signaled he will not sign the coronavirus relief bill passed by Congress unless it amends the massive spending legislation. CNN's Chris Cuomo has more.

item.title: Covid-19 death spike likely fueled by Thanksgiving gatherings and travel
item.description: An average of more than 200,000 people have tested positive for coronavirus every day for two straight weeks in the United States, a toll that has led to record numbers of people hospitalized and dying of the virus.

item.title: Televangelist breaks with Trump: President living in 'alternate reality'
item.description: Televangelist Pat Robertson sided against Trump in his false election conspiracies, saying that Trump lives in an "alternate reality."

item.title: Airline flies passengers to the wrong airport
item.description: Nepali airline Buddha Air made a blunder recently when it flew passengers to the wrong airport.

item.title: 'The Bachelorette' star Tayshia Adams gets engaged on finale
item.description: Tayshia Adams is engaged!

item.title: Highest-paid YouTube star in 2020 is ...
item.description: Ryan Kaji, who reviews toys on YouTube, has been named by Forbes as the platform's highest earner in 2020. His channel, Ryan's World, has more than 12 billion views and he earned nearly $30 million in 2020.

item.title: Georgia student who broke Cayman Islands' quarantine receives reduced sentence
item.description: The Georgia college student who broke Covid-19 quarantine rules in the Cayman Islands to visit her boyfriend has received reduced jail time after initially being sentenced to four months in prison.

item.title: Neighborhood made UPS driver cry tears of joy
item.description: Residents of a Virginia neighborhood surprised their local UPS delivery driver who brought joy to their lives during the pandemic. WTVR's Tracy Sears reports.

item.title: This is the longest music video of all time
item.description: Twenty One Pilots has officially set a new record for the longest music video of all time -- clocking in at just over 4,264 hours.

item.title: 'Tis the season for 'falling iguanas' in South Florida
item.description: The National Weather Service in Miami is calling for "falling iguanas" in its holiday forecast.

item.title: Man becomes overnight sensation after interview with CNN
item.description: CNN's Cyril Vanier catches up with 91-year-old Martin Kenyon, who became an overnight sensation after speaking to CNN when he took his first dose of the Pfizer coronavirus vaccine at Guys Hospital in London.

item.title: Review: 'Wonder Woman 1984' gets dragged down by its uninspired villains
item.description: The adage that a heroic movie is only as good as its villains has never felt truer than in "Wonder Woman 1984," and those villains simply aren't very good. The net effect is a concerted drag on this eagerly anticipated sequel, making its simultaneous debut in theaters and streaming on HBO Max perhaps the film's most memorable footnote.

item.title: 'I have $4 to my name.' An extended eviction ban isn't enough for some struggling renters
item.description: Millions of struggling renters will likely be protected from eviction -- at least for another month.

item.title: Trump administration to purchase additional 100 million Pfizer vaccine doses
item.description: The Trump administration will purchase an additional 100 million doses of coronavirus vaccine from Pfizer, the US Department of Health and Human Services announced Wednesday.

item.title: 'Hundreds' in US could have new Covid strain, researchers say
item.description: Researchers studying the new UK strain of the coronavirus think it likely arrived in the US in mid-November, and that many people in the United States could already be infected.

item.title: This hospital is a perfect microcosm of how Covid-19 is escalating
item.description: In June, Houston's United Memorial Medical Center was so overwhelmed by the pandemic that two of its wings had been transformed into Covid-19 wards.

item.title: Incoming CDC director: What we need to do
item.description: Incoming CDC Director Dr. Rochelle Walensky tells CNN's John Berman what her priorities are in the fight against coronavirus.

item.title: Passenger who jumped out of a moving plane was allegedly about to lose control
item.description: One of the two passengers who exited a Delta flight with their dog as the plane taxied onto a runway felt he needed to leave or he would lose control, according to statements during an arraignment Tuesday.

item.title: United passenger died of Covid-19 and acute respiratory failure, coroner says
item.description: United Airlines is working with the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention to contact anyone who was on board a diverted flight from Orlando to Los Angeles after the death of a passenger who had Covid-19.

item.title: These were CNN's top 100 digital stories of 2020
item.description: You know it's been a remarkable year when a devastating global pandemic isn't the only major story capturing people's attention.

item.title: KFC launches game console that keeps your chicken warm
item.description: Fast-food chain KFC has launched a new Intel-powered games console that comes with a built-in "chicken chamber" to keep your snacks warm.

item.title: Why Jupiter and Saturn's alignment has been nicknamed the 'Christmas Star'
item.description: The solar system's two largest planets crossed paths on Dec. 21, appearing as a double planet in the sky that was nicknamed the "Christmas Star".

item.title: The untold story of Ann Lowe, the Black designer behind Jackie Kennedy's wedding dress
item.description: Some 800 guests saw the dress at the ceremony at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Newport, Rhode Island, and 400 more watched it glide through the reception that evening. And then there were the 3,000 well-wishers who broke through police barricades to witness Jacqueline Lee Bouvier's arrival at her wedding to then Sen. John Fitzgerald Kennedy.

item.title: 3 things that could steal Christmas for Wall Street
item.description: Some of us are winding down for a period of holiday rest after a tumultuous year. But those who work in finance may not get much respite.

item.title: The pandemic is forcing older workers to retire early
item.description: America has gone from having the strongest job market in decades to the very opposite during the pandemic. For older workers who have lost their jobs this year, the state of the labor market makes it harder to get rehired as the economy recovers, forcing many Americans to retire early.

item.title: Elon Musk claims Tim Cook refused to meet with him to discuss buying Tesla
item.description: Tesla CEO Elon Musk said on Twitter on Tuesday that he attempted to sell the company "during the darkest days of the Model 3 program," but that Apple CEO Tim Cook "refused to take the meeting."

item.title: Billionaire Ray Dalio has a warning about America's massive wealth gap
item.description: Ray Dalio, the billionaire founder of the world's largest hedge fund, is deeply worried about a divided and profoundly unequal America as President-elect Joe Biden prepares to take power.

item.title: 21 last-minute gifts your family will actually like
The best sales to shop today: Burrow, AirPods, Dyson and more
33 genius ways to spend your FSA dollars before they expire
The Instagram-famous Always Pan is 20% off with this discount
Our favorite last-minute subscriptions to gift this year
7 great family games for hosting a virtual game night
Start reading more in 2021 with Amazon's best books of 2020
Your guide to buying a running watch
20 gifts the Capricorn in your life will love
I used an iPhone 12 Pro for 2 months. Here are the pros and cons
Last chance: Up to $30 off Amazon with targeted Discover cards
The best coupons at JCPenney
Why we're obsessed with the story of a woman who blew up her career for one of America's most hated men
item.description: It takes a rare, compelling story to go viral on a Sunday night the week of Christmas, but Elle.com managed it with the publication of Stephanie Clifford's "The Journalist and the Pharma Bro," a tale of how former Bloomberg News reporter Christie Smythe torpedoed her career and generally blew up her life for "Pharma Bro" Martin Shkreli, one of the most hated men in America. Shkreli became famous for price-gouging a life-saving drug and magnified his villain status by getting permanently suspended from Twitter for harassing female journalists online. He wound up in prison for fraud, which is where he sits today.

item.title: How Trump's pardons could get even more bizarre
item.description: President Donald Trump announced a wave of pardons on Tuesday for people ranging from Republican allies to two men who pleaded guilty in Robert Mueller's Russia investigation. Meanwhile, speculation grows about whether President Trump will pardon three of his adult children, his son-in-law, or even himself before his term ends on January 20.

item.title: WH staff will move Trump out on Jan. 20, no matter what
item.description: President Donald Trump has refused to say what he will be doing on Inauguration Day. But while the possibility of his shunning President-elect Joe Biden's swearing-in ceremony -- as well as no sign of an invitation for Biden and his wife, Jill, to the White House before Biden's swearing-in -- may earn Trump headlines, it will do nothing to stop one sacred tradition: The White House's dedicated residence staff will be moving the Bidens into the White House and the Trumps out on January 20, whether Trump likes it or not.

item.title: Why billionaires are a policy problem
item.description: On Monday night, Congress finally passed a second relief bill in response to the catastrophic Covid-19 pandemic. The $900 billion package is the first new aid many Americans have seen since March, and the direct payouts — $600 for those making under $75,000, plus a boost of $300 a week to unemployment payments — are half that provided in the spring. Yet even that paltry package was hard-won, as a number of Senate Republicans had initially opposed a second round of relief payments.

item.title: The Confederate flag is a northern problem, too
item.description: Last Thursday, New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo signed legislation prohibiting Confederate flags and other "symbols of hate" from being displayed or sold on state-owned property, including the state fairgrounds. The only exception is when such symbols appear in books or museums, where they may be used for "education or historical purposes."

item.title: The ugly part of the $900 billion stimulus bill
item.description: The new Covid-19 stimulus package will be a great relief for tens of millions of Americans, but the process of getting to it exposed the need to overhaul our broken budget politics. Both parties have been at fault in creating a process that is chaotic, undemocratic and ultimately reckless.

item.title: Here's which Biden Cabinet and other top roles haven't been announced yet
item.description: President-elect Joe Biden has yet to announce several key roles in his incoming administration, including attorney general, labor secretary and commerce secretary.

item.title: Four key ways Barr broke with Trump at the attorney general's news conference
item.description: Two days before he leaves the Justice Department, Attorney General William Barr offered his sharpest rebuke to date of President Donald Trump's baseless allegations surrounding the election result, rejecting Trump's efforts to act on the conspiracy theories the President has embraced to explain his loss to President-elect Joe Biden.

item.title: Key lines from unveiling of Biden's climate team
item.description: President-elect Joe Biden on Saturday introduced key Cabinet nominees and members of his climate team, including New Mexico Rep. Deb Haaland for interior secretary and former Michigan Gov. Jennifer Granholm for energy secretary.

item.title: Analysis: How voters rank Trump a historically bad president
item.description: Poll of the week: A new Fox News poll finds that 42% of voters say history will remember President Donald Trump as one of the worst presidents ever.

Three French police officers shot dead after responding to a domestic violence incident
item.description: Three police officers have been shot dead and a fourth has been injured following a domestic violence incident in central France, local prosecutors told CNN affiliate BFM TV.
